department.en: Faculty of Liberal Arts and Science (Natural Sciences)

description.en: A new field-emission x-ray radiography system based on our design is described. The key component of the system is a triode-type x-ray source with a built-in nanostructured electron source. The electron source is comprised of palladium-induced carbon nanofibers, which continue to field-emit electrons for more than 10 h at 2 X 10(-7) Torr with a fluctuation of +/-8%. Feedback control of the potential of the electron-extracting electrode, or the gate, reduces the current fluctuation to +/-0.5%, but this current regulation does little to improve the image resolution. Our system provides sharp x-ray images of both biological and nonbiological samples. (C) 2004 American Institute Of Physics.

A new field-emission x-ray radiography system based on our design is described. The key component of the system is a triode-type x-ray source with a built-in nanostructured electron source. The electron source is comprised of palladium-induced carbon nanofibers, which continue to field-emit electrons for more than 10 h at 2 X 10(-7) Torr with a fluctuation of +/-8%. Feedback control of the potential of the electron-extracting electrode, or the gate, reduces the current fluctuation to +/-0.5%, but this current regulation does little to improve the image resolution. Our system provides sharp x-ray images of both biological and nonbiological samples. (C) 2004 American Institute Of Physics.

A miniature x-ray tube is described. The tube is made of Kovar, inside which a grounded target is located close to a field-electron emitter consisting of aligned carbon nanofibers, which continues to work for around 100 h in the 10(-6) Pa region unless arcing is induced between the electrodes. The resolution of the contact x-ray images provided by the tube would be impossible using the existing techniques of conventional x-ray radiography, whether the sample is biological or nonbiological. (C) 2004 American Institute of Physics.

paper_title.ja: One- and two-electron excitations in large angle scattering of Li+ ions from He atoms
Interaction potential for Li+-He at small distances

paper_title.en: One- and two-electron excitations in large angle scattering of Li+ ions from He atoms
Interaction potential for Li+-He at small distances
Charge-overlap effect on the electronic transitions in moderate-energy Li+-N-2 and Li+-CO collisions

description.en: A potential model represented by the overlap of electron clouds of interacting particles has been applied to discuss the diabatic potential crossings, which lead to excitations of N-2(a(1)Pi (g)) and CO(A(1)Pi) in moderate-energy Li+-N-2 and Li+-CO collisions, at the specific molecular orientations of gamma = 0 degrees and 180 degrees (linear configuration). The potential crossings in the overlap model originate from the hole produced by the promotion of an electron in the outer a molecular orbitals (MOs) of the N-2 and CO molecules. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Charge-overlap effect on the electronic transitions in moderate-energy Li+-N-2 and Li+-CO collisions

description.en: A potential model represented by the overlap of electron clouds of interacting particles has been applied to discuss the diabatic potential crossings, which lead to excitations of N-2(a(1)Pi (g)) and CO(A(1)Pi) in moderate-energy Li+-N-2 and Li+-CO collisions, at the specific molecular orientations of gamma = 0 degrees and 180 degrees (linear configuration). The potential crossings in the overlap model originate from the hole produced by the promotion of an electron in the outer a molecular orbitals (MOs) of the N-2 and CO molecules. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.ja: Excitation mechanisms in moderate-energy Li+-Ne collisions

paper_title.en: Excitation mechanisms in moderate-energy Li+-Ne collisions
Charge-overlap effect on the electronic transitions in moderate-energy collisions between closed-shell particles with rare-gas structure

description.en: A potential model, which is represented by the overlap of electron clouds of interacting particles, has been applied to discuss the diabatic potential crossings which lead to one- and two-electron transitions in moderate-energy collisions of closed-shell particles. The crossings evaluated with the potential model interpret reasonably well both differential scattering experiments and ab initio calculations. In the model, the potential crossings originate from the hole(s) produced by the promotion of electron(s) in the outermost shell(s) of incident particle(s). (C) 1998 American Institute of Physics. [S0021-9606(98)01046-0].

paper_title.en: Charge-overlap effect on the electronic transitions in moderate-energy collisions between closed-shell particles with rare-gas structure

description.en: A potential model, which is represented by the overlap of electron clouds of interacting particles, has been applied to discuss the diabatic potential crossings which lead to one- and two-electron transitions in moderate-energy collisions of closed-shell particles. The crossings evaluated with the potential model interpret reasonably well both differential scattering experiments and ab initio calculations. In the model, the potential crossings originate from the hole(s) produced by the promotion of electron(s) in the outermost shell(s) of incident particle(s). (C) 1998 American Institute of Physics. [S0021-9606(98)01046-0].

paper_title.en: Excitation mechanisms in moderate-energy Li+-Ar collisions

description.en: By means of differential energy-transfer measurements, excitation processes in Li+-Ar collisions have been studied over a wide range of laboratory angles of 2 degrees less than or equal to theta less than or equal to 92 degrees and at laboratory collision energies of 70 less than or equal to E-lab less than or equal to 2000 eV. The Li+ and Li atoms scattered inelastically were observed at reduced angles of E-lab theta > 5 keV deg, and collision energies of E-lab greater than or equal to 200 eV. At 200 less than or equal to E-lab less than or equal to 350 eV, the inelastic signals are exclusively due to one-electron transitions, while for E-lab greater than or equal to 500 eV two-electron excitation as well as one-electron excitation was observed. The electronic transitions in the moderate-energy Li+ Ar collisions take place at distances of R < R-c = 0.81 Angstrom. The excitation mechanism for one-electron charge transfer having the largest cross section is investigated in detail by referring to nb initio potentials. The angular dependence of the differential cross sections of two-electron transitions at higher energies shows three different types of excitations: the first transition takes place around R-c = 0.75 Angstrom, the second around R-c = 0.47 Angstrom, and the third around R-c = 0.2 Angstrom. The first and second transitions are due to noncrossing interactions, while the third is attributed to avoided crossing.

paper_title.en: Excitation mechanisms in moderate-energy Li+-Ar collisions

description.en: By means of differential energy-transfer measurements, excitation processes in Li+-Ar collisions have been studied over a wide range of laboratory angles of 2 degrees less than or equal to theta less than or equal to 92 degrees and at laboratory collision energies of 70 less than or equal to E-lab less than or equal to 2000 eV. The Li+ and Li atoms scattered inelastically were observed at reduced angles of E-lab theta > 5 keV deg, and collision energies of E-lab greater than or equal to 200 eV. At 200 less than or equal to E-lab less than or equal to 350 eV, the inelastic signals are exclusively due to one-electron transitions, while for E-lab greater than or equal to 500 eV two-electron excitation as well as one-electron excitation was observed. The electronic transitions in the moderate-energy Li+ Ar collisions take place at distances of R < R-c = 0.81 Angstrom. The excitation mechanism for one-electron charge transfer having the largest cross section is investigated in detail by referring to nb initio potentials. The angular dependence of the differential cross sections of two-electron transitions at higher energies shows three different types of excitations: the first transition takes place around R-c = 0.75 Angstrom, the second around R-c = 0.47 Angstrom, and the third around R-c = 0.2 Angstrom. The first and second transitions are due to noncrossing interactions, while the third is attributed to avoided crossing.

paper_title.en: EXCITATION MECHANISMS IN MODERATE-ENERGY NA+-AR COLLISIONS

description.en: By means of differential energy-transfer measurements, excitation mechanisms in Na+-Ar collisions have been studied at laboratory collision energies of 50 less than or equal to E(lab)less than or equal to 1500 eV. In these experiments, doubly differential cross sections have been measured over nearly the whole angular range in the center-of-mass system by simultaneously detecting both scattered and recoiled particles (Na+, Na, Ar+, and Ar) at laboratory angles of 2 degrees less than or equal to theta less than or equal to 92 degrees. The Na+ ions and Na atoms scattered inelastically were observed at reduced angles of tau>3.5 keV deg and collision energies of E(lab)>500 eV. For energies of 500<E(lab)<1000 eV, the dominant inelastic signal is due to one-electron charge transfer, while for E(lab)>1000 eV, two-electron excitation as well as one-electron excitation were observed. The electronic transitions in the Na+-Ar collisions are classified into two types of excitation mechanisms. One type is the one-electron transition that takes place at internuclear distances of R<R(C1) = 1.07 Angstrom. The other type is the one- and two-electron transitions that-occur at distances of R<R(C2)=0.45 Angstrom. These critical distances R(C)=1.07 and 0.45 Angstrom are close to \r(i)+/-r(j)\=0.96 and 0.38 Angstrom, respectively, evaluated from the ionic and atomic radii.

paper_title.en: EXCITATION MECHANISMS IN MODERATE-ENERGY NA+-AR COLLISIONS

description.en: By means of differential energy-transfer measurements, excitation mechanisms in Na+-Ar collisions have been studied at laboratory collision energies of 50 less than or equal to E(lab)less than or equal to 1500 eV. In these experiments, doubly differential cross sections have been measured over nearly the whole angular range in the center-of-mass system by simultaneously detecting both scattered and recoiled particles (Na+, Na, Ar+, and Ar) at laboratory angles of 2 degrees less than or equal to theta less than or equal to 92 degrees. The Na+ ions and Na atoms scattered inelastically were observed at reduced angles of tau>3.5 keV deg and collision energies of E(lab)>500 eV. For energies of 500<E(lab)<1000 eV, the dominant inelastic signal is due to one-electron charge transfer, while for E(lab)>1000 eV, two-electron excitation as well as one-electron excitation were observed. The electronic transitions in the Na+-Ar collisions are classified into two types of excitation mechanisms. One type is the one-electron transition that takes place at internuclear distances of R<R(C1) = 1.07 Angstrom. The other type is the one- and two-electron transitions that-occur at distances of R<R(C2)=0.45 Angstrom. These critical distances R(C)=1.07 and 0.45 Angstrom are close to \r(i)+/-r(j)\=0.96 and 0.38 Angstrom, respectively, evaluated from the ionic and atomic radii.

paper_title.ja: 東北大学で製作した飛行時間分析装置とその特性
paper_title.en: A Time-of-Flight Analyzer at Tohoku University and Its Characteristics.

description.ja: A time-of-flight analyzer with the path length 2.2 m has been constructed and tested by employing a pulsed ion gun. The optimum time resolution achieved in this analyzer was t/Δt = 6500. The time-of-flight apparatus was used for velocity analysis of fast Li atoms produced by charge exchange reactions in moderate energy Li+-Li collisions. The pulsed alkali-ion beams with time duration of a few ns have been formed by chopping the well-collimated continuous beams. For the pulsing a negative square-wave voltage was applied to a pair of condenser plates.
description.en: A time-of-flight analyzer with the path length 2.2 m has been constructed and tested by employing a pulsed ion gun. For the pulsing a negative square-wave voltage was applied to a pair of condenser plates.
